location: A WAITING BUS, (ON THE STUDIO LOT)

text: (to Julie Rich) ++. Over budget? A picture's a success -- who remembers what it cost?  14
(climbing into the bus) Zimmer... I got to give you a message.
(after a beat) From Jake? I got that message. Everybody heard.
Not this message. Pause... Not a move, not a blink from MATT.
I’m fired. That’s the message. MATT’S continued immobility supplies the answer
JULIE RICH and her own camera and sound men. Also a couple of lesser fish in the world of European journalism. ZIMMER (contd. ) So what am I doing going to his party?  15
You're invited.
... With all these stupid dummies -- !
They're invited.
Jokes...
You know how he is sometimes.
I know how he’s getting... JULIE RICH pricks up her ears at this, and signals to her cameraman. MATT catches her at it.

The bus rolling on along the freeway... Aboard there is yet another DOCUMENTARY CAMERA CREW, but most of the passengers are ZIMMER’S SUPERNUMERARY DUMMIES. One of these last is propped up in a seat beside ZIMMER himself. Matt, PAT and MAGGIE are nearby... AL is with MISS RICH.  16
A much livelier scene including the midgets and the girls (the nudes from the steambath)
So here you are in Hollywood, Julie... I bet life was never like this in -- what was that little hick town you were born in -- ? Dijon, France --
(very cool) Oh...?
Yeah, I just remembered. You aren’t French, though -- you’re Polak extraction.
(coldly) You seem to know quite a lot about me, Mr. Kelly.
(giving her the old smile) Call me Matt.
(in a tone of weary bitterness) Old Matt -- he knows just about everybody. He’s on that Committee --  17
Pipe down, Zimmie.
The one that decides if you’re American.
I’m not American...
Maybe you didn’t know these people are still in business.
(a whiff of quiet menace ) We’re in business, Zimmie.
Mr. Hannaford’s investigated me?
Well, not Jake exactly...
(the phone to his ear) No -- he isn’t on our Committee -- The bus starts with a jerk, shaking everybody --
We gotta be a little careful, don’t we?
(to Mlle. RICH) That’s all right, Julie... You don’t have to worry. You're clean.
--. No editing, really -- just the slates cut off...
So what am I going to see -- everything he’s shot up to now?

The first couple reels, Max. The rest’s already out at the ranch... Zarah’s giving him this party, and she invited all these movie freaks... Bleak, blank silence from MAX DAVID. He waits again for some sort of reaction, and once again gets nothing. We'll see the rest of us the stuff when we get there...  19 BILLY (cont) (contd. ) Zarah’s expecting you, Max... So is Jake --
I was expecting him here.

Jammed into the back are the two cinema historians And biographers, HIGGAM and PISTER, also a DOCUMENTARY CREW (sound and camera)... They can see J.J. HANNAFORD in the driver’s mirror; he’s wearing sunglasses... Sitting beside him is his comrade and disciple, the highl successful young film director BROOKS OTTERLAKE. (OTTER- LAKE is also a talented and compulsive impressionist. With JAKE particularly -- with whom he is now, secretly, more than a bit uneasy -- he tends to jump from one “Voic to another.) Another CAMERAMAN IS SQUEEZED next to him. In the back seat: A flurry of hushed haggling between HIGGAM and PISTER, an a perfect frenzy of interviews... PISTER wants to know, among other things, if MR. HANNAFORD considers that “the camera is a phallus?” Maybe JAKE doesn’t hear...  20
Brooksie --
Right here at your side, Skipper.
Know what I want for my birthday?
(indicating the cineastes in the back) Not this, I bet --
I want a drink.
Mr. Hannaford... Do you mind driving a little slower?
Sprawled dangerously on the back of the car, clutching his microphone. THE SOUND MAN (contd. ) I’m afraid I'll fall off...
MAGGIE’S VOICE (0.S.) Aw, come on, Zimmie. Jake’s fine. He’s just like he always was.

(I’m a make-up man)... an expert. All my life I’ve been sticking my nose into other people’s wrinkles. I know the little signs. (after a beat) It's something you could almost... smell. That’s what the gypsies say.
(dismissing foolishness) Gypsies...
Nine months we practically lived with them... Jake’s first picture in Spain. A flamenco guitar is strumming... but gloom hangs heavy over the group of HANNAFORD executives seated among the dummies...
The lights go out... THE FILM begins... 22
(to JULIE RICH) “Matador” -- remember that one?
The new one’s what I care about --
“The Other Side Of The Wind”... (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM)
BILLY, sitting beside MAX DAVID, is doing his best to act as interpreter, salesman and apologist.
This is toward to the beginning... It comes right after what we were shooting today... She leaves the steamroom, and here’s this character waiting for her...
Dale something?  23
John Dale, Max... He’s the kid on the motorcycle. The one in the middle... Silence... THE FILM continues... then CUT TO:
(defensively) Aw, he’s picked ‘em before...
(after a beat) Nobody knows that better than Zimmie... Nobody’s been with him any longer.
Well, I was never a member of the old wolf-pack. If you’re Jewish, to get into that club, you gotta be charming...
You’re charming enough, Zimmie -- (turning back in his seat)  ZIMMER sighs... She reacts to this. 24 MATT (contd. ) You’re just sore about the dummies.
I know how he feels. Zimmie put in a lot of good work for him...
The bridge for Randy Leigh's nose. I created that nose: the famous profile -- it made him a star.
Jake made him a star...
He doesn’t need to make stars -- just movies. MAGGIE (contd.) You don’t think so?
(looking at the dummy) I don’t know what I think of this one --
(under his breath) Who does?  CU: THE DUMMY HEAD...

head_text.subj: THE FILM, (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM)

text: (shots featuring JOHN DALE)... BILLY can’t think of an answer to this.
(after watching in silence for a while) He looks like a girl.
They do nowadays, that’s how they want to look -- It’s the scene, Max...
Which scene?
The scene...
(sarcastic, but not pressing hard) Oh?... And you old guys | are trying to... ‘get with it’ -- ? Is that what this movie’s about? (then after a beat)
He switches on the playback of his 26 MAX DAVID (contd. ) No?... Well, just what is it about?
I’‘ll try to explain, Max -- as we go along...
(to HIGGAM and

All right, men -- let’s get organized... Where shall we start -- where old Dad here ran away to sea? Or way back to the ancestors? (change of voice-- as a cinema freak) They were all actors, weren’t they, Mr. Hannaford? (change of voice) Worse than that -- they were Irishmen. (his own voice) Here’s the original -- not that it’s as good... miniature tape recorder.  A whirring sound and the tape recorder falls silent... During this last he changes cartridges in his tape recorder. 27

(playback) Most of the old actor-managers were micks. Barret, McCullough, Hannaford, O’Neil... What else was there to be? You carried bricks, got into politics or went on the stage. Old Junius Hannaford was pretty big in High Tragedy before the Civil War. And Junius Junior as befits the second generation, made it into High Society -- a pioneer snob blazing the trail for the Kellys and the Kennedys...
That’s a run-out; but I know the rest. Mr. Hannaford’s father went into the movies --
“Mayfair Max -- “”

“Gentleman Jewel Thief” -- right! Y’see, Skipper -- everybody knows everything. He made three of those pictures...  28 He turns on the playback. OTTERLAKE has flicked off the little sound machine... JAKE glances at him sardonically.
THE FILM continues...
(on playback) .-.. And everybody was happy till they found him one Sunday morning in his suite in the old Hollywood Hotel hanging from the chadel -- Censorship?

(doesn’t reply to the question, but returns, a bit defensively, to his former breezy style) After that you had to go to work for a living -- (to those in the back seat) Give the Skipper his hooch, will you --
A brief silence.
According to Jake, the box likes him...
(an indifferent mumble) Box?
The old magic box. If the camera doesn’t like an actor, it just stares... (another beat) That’s what Jake says.
And if the actor doesn’t like the old magic director?...
(vaguely) Yeah...
And the girl? (then, after a beat) How does the box feel about her?

head_text.subj: THE ACTRESS HERSELF, (DRIVING HER OWN CAR)

text: Like everyone else, on her way to the birthday party...  30 contd... She comes to a stop next to JAKE'S car: they’re both waiting for a traffic light.
(aside to JERRY) Pocohontas... (A bit of rather stoogish laughter greets this from the back seat) OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Zarah was gonna invite your man, too... We put a stop to that, I reckon --
(blankly) Nobody can find him. OTTERLAKE turns to look at him... the lights change, JAKE guns the car and it leaps forward (leaving THE ACTRESS behind)
HANNAFORD’S MOVIE (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM) THE ACTRESS featured in a scene now showing on the screen...
She’s an Indian? -- a red Indian?  31
(with a mirthless chuckle) A red, red Indian -- (then rather quickly) In the story... You'll meet her out at the party, Max.
And the boy -- BILLY can think of nothing useful to say to this...
It’s true what Silence... HANNAFORD’S_ MOVIE Continues...
Coming out of a tunnel...

” (contd. ) I hear? (his mike fully erect) Perhaps you’d care to assess the trauma of your father’s suicide as it may have been reflected in your films?  32 PISTER (contd. ) (getting ready to repeat his question) Mr. Hannaford --

(briskly changing voices -- some celebrated and ridiculously inap- propriate character) Mr. Hannaford began his career as a prop an in the old cliff-hangers... Bombs, buzz-saws, pits full of deadly serpents -- he provided all the disasters --
Mumbles...
What?... Of course, it was Hollywood --
(half to himself) Another town of the same name...
(after a brief pause, prompting him) Yeah -- ?  Another tiny pause.
A cross between a small-time mud-show and a mining camp... Exhilarating.
(prompting again) You shared a bungalow with your first leading man -- I even know his name: Frank Fryer. How about that? And I’m the only one that’s not doing a book on you --
Oh -- ?
You aren’t drinking either.
I thought you were, Otterlake --

The whiskey’s for him, Pister, and let’s have it -- ! ...The book, you mean -- ? My book on Hannaford is how I got to Hollywood -- The publishers’ advance... Lots of very busy business in the back seat as JAKE’s drink is prepared and passed up to him...  34 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Five chapters took the two of us two and a half years... I finally had to begin directing movies myself so I could eat.
The rest is history.
And now you’re too busy?
No, but he is -- And take it from me, fellas, he hates being interviewed. That’s what’s making this whole thing today so delightful... Zarah’s idea --
(unnecessarily) Zarah Valeska.

(assuming another famous voice) She is the one giving the party -- (another voice) Yes, and she’s the one dreamed up this crazy communications orgy, where ‘the younger people of the cinema’ -- (in his own voice) -- whatever that means, are let loose on him. Well, happy birthday...  35 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) I donated a lot of my old tapes -- (into yet another impression) Scattered ‘em here and there among you cineastes, just out of kindness. We can spare him a few questions, I figure, if the answers come first. The cineastes in the back seat are too confused by this virtuosity to really take it in. OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Answers are my department... The first Hannaford films? -- Silents, with David Fryer. Action pictures -- (another voice) Plenty of action. Why, Jake and Dave used to strip to the waist every Saturday night, put their two pay envelopes on the mantlepiece and fight each other for the pot... (then, after a moment, in his own voice) Whatever happened to him?
Fryers? I don’t know, kid.  36
They come and they go.
They sure n’hell go.
John Dale, for instance? (HIGGAM is trying to push his way into an exclusive club, but not making it, of course.) TIGHT TWO SHOT: JAKE and
JAKE says nothing... goes on driving. HIGGAM’S VOICE (0.S.) (he doesn’t know when to stop) The latest of all those actors you’ve discovered...

(after a moment, to OTTERLAKE rather than HIGGAM -- almost to himself) Discovered?... Like you went pearling for ‘em and squeezed your movie star out of an oyster...  37 A title is flashed on the screen. “SCENE MISSING” The screen is in --
Just how much is missing?
Not too much, really -- To BILLY’S relief the title is now replaced on the screen by -- HANNAFORD’S FILM...
What happens here? BILLY’S VOICE (unhappily) I’m not really sure, Max. Maybe it’s here she leaves the bomb...

What’s the bomb for? BILLY’S VOICE (with a short nervous laugh) Jesus, I don’t know...  38 Another title: “SCENE MISSING” BILLY'S VOICE (contd. ) Maybe he’s changing his mind, and there won’t be any...
A rough looking character roars past JAKE’S car on a motorcycle, then slows, signalling...
That cop back there -- he’s waving at ya...
Wave back Brooksie.
You guys are overloaded --
Thanks, Jack.
Somebody’1l have to go --
Can he go with you, Jack?  39
I don’t have the insurance... See ya at the party -- He roars away up the road...
Do I have the pleasure?
He knows you, all right --
(the one in front) Pretty good director --

He thinks he is you. (then, with a quick grin) But don’t we all? Meanwhile, PISTER is about to be tossed out on his ear. It seems that the law won’t allow the SOUNDMAN to ride on the trunk of the car, so room has to be made for him on a seat. As things work out, it’s not HIGGAM but PISTER who is ejected, tape recorded and all...
40 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (speaking the name with distaste) Simon. Jack Simon
(starting the car) Yeah?
A brand new bottling work has been opened at Mac Factor’s just to keep the boy supplied with blood. As the car drives away, PISTER is left with his tape recorder all forlorn on the roadside.
If he didn’t just walk off the set -- if he quit the picture -- How’1l you finish it?
He’1l come back...
What if he doesn’t?  41
Well... Jake’s got a whole lot of ideas --
Such as?
(struggling to find something to say) There isn’t too much I can tell you, Max. You know how much of the picture he just carried in his head... HANNAFORD’S FILM continues... Then --
it screams by overhead... We are in:
An hysterical little episode in which another car in the birthday party procession catches up with
is forcibly added to his passenger list and now it’s HIGGAM who is ejected, tape recorder and all.
(irritably) -.--So what are the toys about?

(increasingly on the defensive) Well... before this, she’1l be pretending to look in the window at ‘em -- That is, when we get around to shooting it -- But really she was just making sure nobody’s following her.
The boy’s been following her -- she’s got to know that.
(starting to drown slightly) Others, beside him... like the FBI or something.
She’s some kind of crook?
Some kinda radical, Max (interrupting himself speaking quickly)  43 BILLY (contd. ) Anyway, there’s some shops there, and the boy thinks she’s been looking at this doll...
(flatly) Which doll -- ?
(after a short silence) The one he thinks she was looking at. So... he goes in and buys it for her... (he offers this last as though it explained
everything) MAX DAVID sighs quietly, but makes no comment.
It stops as PISTER signals to it... He climbs aboard.
(to PISTER) Having fun, Mr. Pister?
The people in that last car were kind of awful.  44
Mr. Hannaford’s car?

They threw me out. And then I was picked up by a lot of video-freaks -- But they ran out of gas, or needed to fix something... As he takes a seat in what might be called the executive section, the bus starts up again...
(well along with his drinking) Hippies... (he pats the top of the dummy’s head) That’s what junior here is all about.
(looking closely at the dummy ) John Dale...?
(to MATT) The hair... that doesn’t make him a hippie. Kids today --
(cutting him off) Yeah?... What do you know about it?  45
What does Jake know -- at his age?
He’d better know.
I’ve got some material on that... PISTER fiddles with his tape recorder.
(dropping his voice) The way I heard it, he’s putting up his own money --
(cutting him off with the answer) The banks wanted a name.
(indicating the dummy) And Jake wanted him... They all stare at the dummy . A baby.
The world’s full of ‘em, Zimmie, or haven't you noticed?
HANNAFORD‘S FILM continues on the screen... MAX DAVID finally breaks the silence:
(a hint of weariness) What’s in the package? BILLY clears his throat nervously.
The package... Y’mean what she’s got in her bag?
It’s either a bomb on her lunch -- huh?
The kid’s package -- (quick change of tone) You saw it already, that’s the doll.. Once again the title appears on the screen:
(carefully patient) Just tell me this, Jimmy --  47
Billy --
There going to be film where it shows there’s a doll in this package?
That’s easy, Max -- just an insert...
And the bomb?
Yes, Max?
If it was left in the building, when does it blow up?
The bomb is... Well, we don’t actually know...
(cutting in) What do we know?
(at the end of his tether) Better ask Jake.
I'd better read a script. (another brief silence) You haven’t got one? -- (this next is not a question) Jake is just making it up as he goes along.
(weakly) He’s done it before...
Look what he did with the other: Glen Garvey... Courtney Saxon --
Courtney? He was selling vacuum cleaners when Jake discovered him.
(disregarding this last) And as for Hannaford himself --
(quickly) What about him?
Branch Sutter -- he was a dish- washer...
(staring at the dummy) Could be that he’s wrong this time...
Who says so?
(turning to look out the window) Zimmer. He’s got this sensitive nose.
That’s all right, Maggie; never mind the smell -- Everything stinks a little.
You’re telling mother.
«+. When I’m done with an actor -- I’m done. He’s as dead as cold mutton...  50
LUCAS listening to the playback on his tape recorder...
It’s like the end of a love affair -- All you want is out... JAKE is speaking to his young friend OTTERLAKE but this is being photographed and recorded in triplicate.
Well, that’s what he got.
For the director, you know -- it’s a kind of...phony honeymoon. You're the groom: You gotta make a fair job of romancing the poor cows.
Suddenly PISTER’S tape recorder comes shrilly (HAND WRITTEN NOTE: to life: “INCOMPLETE” ] MATT’S VOICE (playback) Speak for yourself, Skippper --  MATT laughs in 51
(on camera) That’s you Matt --
We know ‘em, uncle -- we have to...
That’s Mr. Hannaford --
Shhh -- !

We gotta know about everybody -- The creeps and freaks aren’t as much fun as the real gypsies, but something sets our teeth on edge, we do the chic and manly thing, Matthew -- We don’t sulk and turn away. No. We bend over and take a good hard sniff. MATT’S VOICE You don’t have to bend over to smell a hippie. He’s like a polecat; he meets you more than half way. appreciation of his own recorded remark.
(on camera) Like the gypsies, huh, Zimmie?  52
Gypsies?... PISTER is searching in his files, looking up ‘G’ for ‘gypsy’...
It's what the gypsies can smell -- right, Zimmie? ["YES"]
(an irritated mumble) Death... anybody could smell it...
Aw, put a can on it --
He’s turning sour, Matt... He’s going bad. LUCAS’ VOICE «+. Dream projections of Hannaford himself?
Driving very fast, concentrating on the job. TRUMAN LOCKWOOD is sitting  53
Beside her with his camera. In the back are CICCIO TUCCI, a cameraman from Rome, and LUCAS RENARD.
Man, they’re real -- He made ‘em real; gave ‘em existence -- he moulded the clay --
Or cut ‘em out with a pair of scissors.
He conceived ‘em... Like a god.
(under her breath)

-- a terrible and jealous god... That's just what he’s been for this new boy of his. John Dale is Hannaford’s personal creation -- (lowering his voice) There’s something else, too... an even stronger claim... (with a smile) Very much in the Hannaford style...  54
PISTER has been searching in his files, looking up ‘G’ for ‘gypsy’...
(bringing forth a sheet of paper) Here we are -- ‘Gypsies’ -- Transcribed from my own tapes. I was there when he said it... (handing the paper to Pat) Here...

(reading) ‘Gypsies -- Hitler got rid of them, too. But he could have fumigated the whole world, and there’d still be the other ones -- the hippies and beatniks -- the bums... Call ‘em what you want to, they slack and slouch around on the floor because they like it down there. Talk about the return to the womb? What about the return to the cave? Junk... Junk is how you get there... That's how you dig your way back... Junk for the cool dreams, kid; and the cool, dim, anonymous gang-bang... the mutual jack-off’... (he laughs)  55 PAT (contd.) That’s sure tellin’ it like it
Now PAT’S VOICE is replaced by JAKE'S issuing tinnily from the speaker of a tape recorder:
«+. Randy Moore, for instance: he was a prop-boy... David Leigh was an extra: Neil Trevor, Branch Sutter... We see:
Then a wider angle shows us:
(Where LUCAS is playing this tape)

I happened to notice ‘em... But Dale I found. Literally. Fished him out of the sea. Now that’s what you’d call a discovery... Dale was flapping around like something you bring up in a net... BILLY’S VOICE (playback) You should have thrown him back. He was too small.  56
(quickly to the others) Just listen...
(playback) You had to go and make him an actor --

We did what we could. Kept him on the yacht; signed him on as a deck- hand, made a sailor out of him. Or tried to... Sure I rescued him. (grimly; after a moment ) I’ve been rescuing him ever since. C.U. LUCAS as he turns off the playback.
You get it? He saved the cat’s life.
(turning to THE ACTRESS -- half questioning) So John Dale’s in debt to the old man for that...?
(earnestly) Can you imagine a relationship more all-consuming? -- between master and slave?
57 She goes on driving and makes no comment.
Heavy silence from MAX DAVID as HANNAFORD'S FILM conitnues on the screen... A FLASH OF BILLY’S
Silence...
(plaintively) Understand, Max -- This isn’t even a rough-cut... (beginning to betray a certain desperation) You’re going to have to see the entire movie --
Sure. And Jake’s going to have to shoot it --
Like I told you, Max, an awful lot of the footage is out at the ranch. We'll be screening it for you at the party.  58 [“DON'T HAVE” ] MAX DAVID sits, sphinx-like staring at the empty screen...

This is at the HANNAFORD RANCH (in a room used for film projection)... No theatre-type seats here, just a mixture of chairs and couches. These are occupied now by a variety of guests... To celebrate J.J. HANNAFORD’S birthday, ZARAH VALESKA has invited the widest possible range of cineastes and cinema buffs. She has managed to include such men as CHARBOL, GODARD, RHOMER, TRUFFAUT and BURTOLUCCI, as well as some of the brighter young Spaniards and Englishmen. And of course, there are premier figures from the younger Americans: JACK NICHOLSON, DENNIS HOPPER, CASSAVETES, NAZURSKY, HENRY JAGLOM -- the whole spectrum, from video-freaks to ANDY WARHOL. By no means all of these are already here in this pro- jection room. Many are scattered about the ranch, arguing together or just quietly getting stoned. It’s still early...
(one of the celebrities) Hey, that’s the Baron -- Ask him...
(to THE BARON, who has just looked in at the door) We'd like to see the movie --  59
(politely) We've got all night for it... g g. ["DON'T HAVE” ] (as he turns to go) Lots of people haven’t arrived --

head_text.subj: THE DESERT ROAD AND DRIVEWAY LEADING UP TO THE RANCH

text: [“YES" ] Night is falling fast as cars and buses jam into the driveway. Guests of every description are piling out and climbing the picturesque stairway leading up through the great rocks to the ranch-house above... They are pursued (as is just about everyone this evening) by zoom lenses and “sun guns.” SERIES OF SHOTS: (EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR) [“NO” ] In_ conversations such as the following, the actual speakers are only occasionally to be found directly on camera. The voices, for much of the time, Functioning as a sort of informal chorus. OSSAWATOMIE DULUTH: (we are picking this up in the middle of another argument): ++. we’re not inny of us gonna lose inny sleep ovah Hannaford... (NOTE: This is an approximation of OSSIE'S accent. It is given here merely as_a_ sample and will not be repeated. DELLA: Look -- I’ve known everybody -- OSSIE: I don’t deny him one single white hair on his chest, lovely -- DELLA: And nobody's in his league --  60 OSSIE: But as a film-maker -- KLEE: For us, Jake is Scotch whiskey, and red steaks -- TRUMAN: Well, I wouldn’t put Hannaford with people like Renoir or Eisenstein. Sorry -- Einstein.

In the arms of grips, bus-boys, ZIMMER’S whole collection of dummies, emerging from the bus, proceeds grotesquely upwards... Besides the arrival of students, scholars and other cinema celebrities, the different cameras are recording a mixed bag of “Beautiful People” (among whom OSSIE is a popular figure). These people don’t count for much among the film-makers, but they’re here -- along with the midgets, the nudes from HANNAFORD’S movie, and a surly tribe of video-freaks). (These conversations are merely accompaniment: ) SUZIE: Quite a spread... TRAVIS: The late and next to last Mrs. Hannaford, of course, was loaded. TONY: You should see the farm out in Kenya -- LIZA: Oh, that’s gone now -- And the yacht... One of the numberless cameras recording all of this browses for a moment over the fierce shapes of big game heads decorating some of the walls.  61
(looking up at a tiger's head) We got that one the hard way --
The hard way -- ? Standing up ina hammock? (change of tone) Where’s the High Priestess?
Zarah Valeska? Actually, Fiona’s doing her... in black and white.
Priestess of what -- ?
The Clan, honey -- (with heavy sarcasm) The wild and woolly old Hannaford wolf-pack -- (to DELLA) Black and white?  62
Well, it’s her period...
It's certainly his --
Fiona’s even got old Otto what’s- his-name on the camera.
Sounds campy to me.
Campy? That early Hannaford style is --
(over-lap) Von Stroheim --
(cutting her off) Yes, you’re thinking of Von Stroheim.  63
Von Sternberg...
Zarah Valeska -- Take Two! He exits with his slate. We are confronted with:
OTTO, (a nice, tired old cameraman) has triumphantly Managed the correct, classic arrangement of lights... A pause, We are in:

With cool, professional patience, ZARAH is submitting herself to a filmed inter- view conducted by the metallic FIONA DE LALLY (of day-time T.V. Fame), whose voice, after a short, tense silence, comes brightly from behind the lights:
Zarah, you name has been linked romantically with quite a few celebrities... Her voice trails away into silence.  64
(pained but still polite) Wasn’t it understood that we were going to talk about love affairs?
(to the camera crew) Cut!
Cut!

(quietly pained) What you agreed to talk about is Mister Hannaford -- The cameras have stopped (but not that of the DOCUMENTARY MAKER who is covering this froma semi-hiding place) ZARAH'S patience remains monumental. ZARAH (contd. ) (a helpful suggestion) I can tell you a story...
All right, darling... if you want to.
Zarah Valeska -- take Four!  65
(starting her anecdote) One night...
(a hurried whisper) Call me “Fiona” while you’re on camera, darling: it’s so much warmer... Go on...
This is many years ago in Paris -- a big, open Bugatti turned and stopped directly in front of me --
(prompting unneces-— sarily, with a dry toothed smile of professional interest) -- And this was Jake, of course?
(coolly, patiently helpful) It's how we first met, you understand -- in the street. He just thought he was picking up a whore --
Ouch...! Wait a minute --  66
(in her wide-eyed way) Whores are out?
(sweetly chiding) It’s a woman’s program, dear.
It's a woman’s profession. VOICES are heard calling from various parts of the ranch: “He's coming -- !” “It’s Hannaford -- “Here he is -- !"
Do we cut?
(quietly raging) What do you think?
Cut!  67 Pandemonium! A crush of cameras and cineastes...

head_text.subj: THE BIG ROOM IN THE RANCH-HOUSE

text: (like most of our incidental scenes, this plays quickly but takes much longer to describe.) At first we catch only glimpses of JAKE, ringed by blinding circles of sun-guns and flash-bulbs...
One of the friendlier cineastes, flushed with drink and indignation, is arguing with some of HANNAFORD'S attackers:
-- a fascist, for Chrissake? Jake --?
You got the wrong man, fellas; how about Jack Simon here?
You tell us, Brooksie.
(to the others) It’s in his contract -- Every picture he directs, he gets to shoot all the animals, personally. With a gun, that is. They even pay him off in guns --  68
They pay me money, kid.
(fixing SIMON with a hard smile) And they say I imitate him.
(with a quiet menace ) That’s your thing, Otterlake. real good at imitations...
(called MAVIS) Do Jack Benny --

JAKE is changing a big empty glass for a very full one. His eyes are on THE ACTRESS. (She pays no attention to him)... ABE VOGEL. The distin- guished Hollywood agent, makes his way through the milling crowds to JAKE'S side.
Hi there, Jake -- Happy birthday...
JAKE, entering the scene, cheerfully sabotages his own defense: 69
Shall we define our terms?
Shall we not.
Spades, spics, micks, hunkies, honkies and hebes -- There’s a few terms for ya... (burlesque red- neck) A fassatist now -- he don’t like them people --
(behind JAKE) And what kind of people do you like?
(with a benign all- embracing smile) Nobody. (turning to VOGEL) Abie -- ! How nice to see you looking so old.  70
(to JULIE, dip- lomatically) Nobody in the plural...
Then who in the particular? JAKE turns to her with that maddeningly blank look of his -- (like the proud parent of a hope- less brat)... Silence... then --
High on the great boulders which loom decoratively over the swimming pool, JOEY (a PROP MAN) can be seen arranging the dummies in a long row on the rocks. He calls down:
Okay?
Fine, Joey. (he turns to
So how do they look?  71 ZIMMER (contd. ) (after a beat) Stupid, that’s how they look...

head_text.subj: THE VALESKA TV _ INTERVIEW, (IN THE LIBRARY)

text: (coming on strong) Darling, this marvelous bash you're giving him... As I hear it, your whole idea was to get Hannaford in touch with the new generation...
And vice versa --
And that’s why so few of your guests are his own age -- ?
Most people of Mister Hannaford’s age are too old for him...
A minority group of well-established Hollywood citizens.  72
(winding up a little speech) ++. Screen Director's Guild waiting around on their tired old asses for the phone to ring. His ass is tired too, but he don’t sit on it. Jake gets out and hustles.
Sure -- just to keep up all of this...
Who says he’s keepin’ it up? I hear he’s in trouble...
Power...
What?

Look at the dictators... Symphony conductors -- look at them. Power -- that’s the answer. Y’don’t keep goin’ just playin’ golf. Geta country under you, or a whole orchestra -- that charges up the old batteries...  73 FOURTH CITIZEN (contd. ) He stops -- catching sight of JAKE, who has come up behind them, drink in hand... How about it?
(a sardonic lifting of one eyebrow) Give me an orchestra and we'll see.
(who has been lurking B.G.) And go on playing the same old piece?
(with perfect serenity) Nice to see you, kid. JAKE smiles sweetly at him...
We do chug along a little, Mr. Simon, with the times...
Which times? -- and who are you?
There never was an artist yet who didn’t work from memory.
The Baron is in charge of metaphysics.
(turning on SIMON) And who got him an invitation?
“Confrontation” is the word, Abie. Take it up with our hostess.
Zarah? She must be nuts. JAKE has just caught sight of a cute little blonde -- a very young one...
Mother seems to think a little young blood’1l be good for us --  75
(lecherously registering the young
She could be right at that!
She’s always right... Excuse me, fellas, but I think we got ourselves a confrontation... He starts moving in on his target. The CITIZENS chuckle appreciatively as they sit watching his progress.
He’s got another motivation --
I’ll say --
(soberly) The one that matters. He’s in love --
Get off it, he’s too old for that --
JULIE RICH’S GROUP 76
Some people never are. You'd be surprised at how much mustard’s being cut in the old people’s home.
So who’s he in love with -- Zarah?
The movies.
(in his solemn Dutch accent) I dig... It is not that he not make female stars -- it is just that he did not make them stars --
That's my whole thesis --
Great thesis, the old man can still score --
Who says so -- ?  77
How he scores -- who he scores with... That, my friends, gets us into some very interesting country...

head_text.subj: THE BLONDE, (IN A TIGHT GROUP SHOT)

text: JAKE lays a hand on OSSIE’S shoulder. He turns back to the
Hi -- !
Jake -- I think you know Ossawatomie Duluth...
Ill-met by candlelight, proud Titania! Ossie... we like your little friend.
(putting an arm around her) Not his, Skipper. She’s mine.
(disregarding this, bending his good ear to her and oozing charm) What’s your name, sweetie?  JULIE RICH’S GROUP 78
Mavis Henscher.
--. Oh, yes, his partners are female. Certainly... But which females?
You tell us -- albinos with wooden legs?
Tomorrow's Sunday, Mavis... you’ll be flying down with us to Mexico.
What for?
Piedras Negras.
Who?
Bulls.
Pardon?
Dangerous breed, sweetie.
One of them once killed a friend of ours --
(closing in for the kill) Tomorrow we’re going to see what happens to our new boy.
(losing patience) So the old man has a kink or two -- what of it?
(quietly serious) The old man is a destroyer.
What he creates, he has to wreck. It's a compulsion.  80
It’s a theory.
I’ve got names and dates... The folder she’s holding is, indeed, rather suggestive of a dossier. But before we can hear more of this --
Gee, I don’t know... I’ve got school on Monday.
(grinning at the others) I‘ll write a note to the teacher.
ZIMMER, his make-up box at his side, sitting glumly in front of his dummies, all arrayed before him...
How could I -- ?
Come on in and have a drink, Zimmie --
I don’t know these people. Why they’s leadin’ actors nowadays -- stars even -- I don’t know their names.
(phone still to his ear, he idicates ZIMMER’S dummies) Y‘don’t know his name --
John Dale?
(with grim satis- faction) Oscar. That’s his real name... In his school days whataya think he was famous for -- ?
Fornication.
(with grim satis- faction) We got us somebody tonight who’s gonna tell us all about it -- (into phone) Yeah?  82
(looking up at the dummies ) Quite impressive, I just say. (he indicates the dummies )
So is Mr. Dale. To look at him you'd swear he was real.
(speaking into JAKE'S ear, the full Mafioso) New information -- about Dale...
Well, Uncle Matthew?
We found out where he comes from -- A big, rich family out in Iowa...
How do you like those apples? Your starving orphan went to boarding school --  Silence... 83
We got one of his teachers. Want to see him?
(after a beat) Sure. Pipe him aboard, Uncle Matthew.
He’s coming out with Billy.
Fine. Billy’s bringing Max --
Yeah, when’s he joining the party? (something in MATT'S eye stops her)
He isn’t.
Any word from Texas?
I sent a car out to the airport...  Another short silence... He smiles sweetly at them all and moves away...
Jake -- Can I start the screening? Half the kids are in there waiting...
Think some of them went to expensive boarding schools? Give ‘em three reels or so, and pass among ‘em with a tin cup.
The Hannaford Mafia isn’t looking very festive --
Yeah... I wish they’d go home...
Trouble?
Four days... that’s a long time, Brooksie.
Till what? MAVIS THE BLONDE dances up to JAKE with another stiff whiskey. He accepts it gratefully. He urges her away... Then turns back to JAKE.
Thanks, sweetie... Where’s your former boyfriend?
(moving into scene) He’s here and your going to the movies --
What?
(firmly) Just follow the crowd... What's Friday?
Friday we close down.  86
Jesus... A crowd of guest passes by on the way to the screening... You can’t finish the picture in four days --
(raising his glass) I’ve been over-schedule before. Let’s drink to that...
How many times have you been broke, Skipper? A short, tense pause...
At my present age, Brooksie -- just once.

head_text.subj: THE PROJECTION ROOM AT THE RANCH

text: Lights dim out, there are the usual stirrings and throat-clearings... Then, on the screen we resume: HANNAFORD’S FILM

The door to this (part-time) projection room is important: when people open it, their silhouettes move across the screen. THE ACTRESS is the first to make such an entrance and, as she finds herself a place, is the cause of interested attention... Later there’s another interruption: the opening door (the square of light blanking out part of the screen -- the crouching and ducking silhouettes as new arrivals sneak heavily into the room). This time it’s JULIE RICH with a couple of journalist colleagues. They make a dash for it into the darkest corner of the room. Here, there aren’t any chairs, but the view of the screen in unimpeded, so they sit on the floor. ROGER and DENISE KLEE (a film-making partnership) are squatting nearby, their backs to the wall. Soon others in the room become aware of a low and rather venomous buzzing from the corner.
(addressing JULIE
Don’t try to lay that on us --
(total incredulity) You can say almost anything else about him --  They do, but for the moment they shut up. THE FILM continues... 88
(elaborately patient, wind- ing up an argument ) If -- and I say “if,” mind you -- actually going to bed with a boy is the only definition you'll accept --
Shhh -- !
Do you mind -- ?  89 A WINDOW IN THE “PROJECTION ROOM” OTTERLAKE stands looking in at the FILM being projected now for the guests...
Hey -- put Hannaford there... There, where you’re standing.
(grinning) Come on, cooperate...
What for?

The reflection in the glass -- The face and the film inside -- a real Hannaford set-up! During this OTTERLAKE has laughingly urged JAKE into place. Now, as the camera turns, he fills in the lull with a quotation:
“These, your actors, were all spirits- And are melted into air... Into thin air...”  90 JAKE has started a long pull at his drink but is interrupted by the voice of JULIE
Tatum, Fryer, Leigh... Branch Sutter... Garvey... He smiles at her... Then, after a short silence:
Absent friends.
And John Dale... All made by you --. Funny. We don’t see one of those men tonight at your party.
Tonight is for the freaks and snoops, lady -- If you’ll excuse us, please...
Why don’t you go in and see the movie, lady -- like everybody else? They wait for her to go... She does.  91
“Thin air...”

“And like the baseless fabric of this vision, shall dissolve...” Did you know they had dissolves in Shakespeare? (playing it up a little for the benefit of the camera) Sure he does: he knows everything in Shakespeare. “The Hannaford family curse -- ”
And he knows everything about the Hannafords; that’s my curse...
We all know about old Grandad, Junius the First -- “The great Irish tragedian in the tinseled toga -- “
The Shakespeare comes from him, all right.  92
Handed down, with a few other things -- “Booze and the Bard” -- Right?... As for the booze part of it -- Well, if he hasn’t quite made it asa rummy -- nobody can say he hasn’t tried!
I’m seeing little pink directors at this very minute.
But Junius -- Ah, “there was a most distinguished souse”... Another line of yours.
That's what’s so nice about Brooksie -- I don’t have to repeat myself, he does it for me...
(continuing to quote) “ -~ BR noble Roman shanty Irishman; Sure, even when he cut his wrists and killed himself...” (looking around) We've lost our camera, haven’t we?
You’re losing me.  Pause... A pause... 93

“Like Seneca, old Junius bled to death in a bathtub -- one of the few times he ever sat in one. But Junius Junior -- ” (that’s your daddy) “He even made it into High Society -- a pioneer among the micks, blazing the trail for the Kellys and the Kennedys... Piss-elegant. He chose the chandelier...”
A human tape recorder.
That's me, Skipper.
I didn't know you had the chandelier.
I’ve got everything. In the old Hollywood Hotel it was... They found him, one Sunday morning, hanging from it. After which you had to go to work for a living... As a prop man, etcetera...  94
Yeah... you got it all.

I’m the Authority. (Is there -- behind the complacency of that statement -- an overtone of old affection still remaining? If so, it rings a little false in JAKE'S ears... Somehow his young friend has staked out a claim of ownership)... He looks at him with something very cold in his eyes... OTTERLAKE smiles back at him with proprietory approval... OTTERLAKE (contd. ) So... what do we do next?

We never know, do we? A pause... JAKE is in a sort of reverie... This has commenced earlier and comes from thoughts far removed from family anecdotes...  He raises his glass as 95 JAKE (contd. ) We're feeling fine -- it’s early morning --
Not quite yet.

This is a flash-back... You just happen to notice somebody trying to drown himself. Some young pink nobody ever heard of. And how's this? After you dry him out, you try to get him interested in staying dry... Hell, you can recite that story backwards. And it’s lousy -- I can’t get him interested in anything. Everything’s a drag, man -- Be a movie actor? That just bores him to death... He doesn’t die, though; no, he’s cured of that. He merely kicks me rather sharply in the groin and walks away... though offering a toast. Speaking of suicides.
Come on, Skipper -- let’s go to the movies... They start away together.
One group (among all the groups) clustered around LUCAS, or some other CINEASTE... He’s holding up his pocket tape recorder.
Listening to the recorded voices.
(on the playback) ... Reflection of your attitude -- right, Mr. Hannaford? God isn’t dead -- ?
(playback) Well, kid -- He’s certainly Jewish.
What’s that about?
One of my tapes. I’ve donated them to the cause.
Tapes -- from that book you're doing?  97
From the book we're not doing... I’m the little corner store, Abe, that has to give way to the supermarket.
You’re the only big director who ever tried to write about him.
I had to stop trying.
But you two are friends... Close friends --
(lurking at OTTER- LAKE’S shoulder) That's what interests me: just how close you are...
Abe, this is Juliette Rich, the distinguished critic. Abe Vogel, the dean of Hollywood agents... Miss Rich is doing a “study in depth” -- and she’s so far down she’s got the bends. (turning to the
What happened to the tape?  Laughter... OTTERLAKE grins and continues: 98
I’m changing it.

Don’t bother. I know all the material ... Religion? Here it is, The Gospel According to Jake: “God the Gather is an old Jew invented by a lot of other old Jews in a hopeless attempt to put down the Jewish Mother.” He says that’s what it’s all about -- the whole new scene... Even his movie --
(cutting in sharply) How’s that again -- ? His mov --
(cutting her off in turn, very quickly) The kids -- they're all turned on to Her...
The Jewish mother?  More laughter... Total silence follows that... The crowd is startled 99
(Louis Armstrong or Flip Wilson) God? -- She sure is a mother -- !
(unsmilingly) You said about his mov --

(now it’s his turn to cut her off) We don’t talk about the movie. by his sudden appearance, and also (JAKE himself feels) a bit dashed by the abruptness of his tone... He smiles his most benevolent and priestly smile. Try the Baron here... Under torture he might squeal a little. He writes the scripts --
So Mr. Hannaford likes to say --  This stops her dead in her tracks... 100
(to THE BARON) Then this is your idea-- ?
(amiably blank) What idea?
(losing her cool a little, she has a hunch they're putting her on) Don’t pretend to be stupid. You're the brainy one in this famous club of yours -- or “Clan: or whatever you call it --
It's a highly informal organization.
That tape we were hearing -- the subject was God... Is He a member?
She.  101
You heard the man, lady.
I heard you imitating him.
He does other people better.

(as Jack Benny) Well -- It came to Our Prophet in a blinding flash of light, that Old Mister White Whiskers has shot his last thunderbolt, so... we’re back where we started -- (his own voice) -- Back to Mamma. (playing to the gallery) His words, mark you -- The Last of The Male Chauvinists --
(a sneer out of the shadows) I like him as Hannaford. That’s his beat. You’d swear he is Hannaford.
(with an icy smile) That's real nice, Jack -- coming from you.  JAKE intervenes, patching up a nasty little moment between 102 the two young directors. Laughter and some applause...
We’re all ruled by the wind, aren't we, lady? So if the Lord is a lady, and God's will is Her will -- then we can relax, can’t we? And stop expecting the universe to be logical.
Thus spaketh Jake. JULIE RICH is slightly dazed by all this glib recitation, but she makes a quick, if slightly lopsided recovery.
(indicating
And how does your disciple feel about the new film --
(cutting this subject off again) He’s the apostle, lady.  (JAKE, of course, is putting her on; and OTTERLAKE plays up to 103 it -- drawing, as usual, on his powers of memory and mimicry)

Sure, just like St. Paul... (aside to JAKE) I know the lyrics for that one, too. (in JAKE'S voice) Paul was a big man, y'know. He put it all together, packaged it -- (in his own voice) Sounds like a producer. (as JAKE again) Well, kid, he got the final cut. Jesus was dead -- the subject was in public domain when old Paul dreamed up Christianity, and stuck then “anity” into Christ --

As long as I’m still twitching, Brooksie -- you ain’t gonna stick it into me. JULIE RICH does not fail to catch the veiled aggression in this last...  104 (During this last MAVIS, OTTERLAKE’S young blonde has tripped into scene bearing a stiff drink for JAKE) OTTERLAKE glances quickly at JAKE... who is smiling at JULIE with an air

(to JAKE) Isn’t that just what he’s doing? ... Otterlake’s new picture is breaking the house record at the Music Hall, and when his own production company goes public, they say he’1ll walk away with forty million dollars...
And you'll say I stole it all from Mr. Hannaford... I’1l never walk away from that.
(sibylline) Yes... you two have to stick together. of perfect benevolence...
Please don’t tell us what you mean by that.  105
(with a leer) Whatever it means, you hadn’t ought to be impertinent to an Apostle...
(with some petulance) Hey, this is a drag -- how did we get off into religion -- ?
To get away from movies. (back to JULIE) The name of the game, lady.
(pouring a little oil on the troubled waters) We should get away from both. A mystery should be left in peace.
(a voice from the outlying suburbs of this group) Mystery -- ?  Miss RICH thinks she has a smart answer to that one: 106
Games are only fun till someone loses.
(irritated to find himself so much out of his depth) What mystery?
(smiling at

I’m a good loser, lady -- a lovely loser. (to VOGEL) Movies and friendship... those are mysteries... (was there just a tiny sting in the last?... Anyway, his tone brightens abruptly) And religion... The Baron’s into that but also I know his material -- (as THE BARON) “A mystery may reveal, it never explains.”  107
Like Mr. Hannaford --
(quickly, brightly) Right, sweetie. Just like me and God. He started to go, but turns back for the curtain line: If it weren’t for the difference of sex, how could you tell us apart?

Continues... And now, another interruption: There is a low buzz of interest as JAKE’S shadow is cast upon the screen... Drink in hand, he takes a chair at the side of the room and sits there watching... From the SOUND-TRACK he can hear his own voice (picked up on the set by his own micro- phone -- speaking from behind his own camera) issuing directions to the actors -- giving quiet but insultingly obscene commands to the actor JOHN DALE by way of guiding the erotic action... (The sequence is the one on the rusty wreck of a bed in the back-lot of the abandoned movie studio)... Suddenly a voice is heard in the projection room itself:
(hoarsely vulgar) We oughta be coming soon to that shot where he walked off The picture... huh, Mr. Hannaford?...  109 No reply to this from JAKE... THE VOICE in the audience persists --

Sure; they got it all on filn, y‘know,... I was there; Jake went right on cranking: the whole thing -- where he marches straight out of the studio bare-assed... Again, no comment from JAKE... And now, as he sits watching it, we come to that moment in the action (THE GIRL’S scissors on THE BOY’S hair) when JOHN DALE jumps up off the bed, strides through the mass of movie equipment, off the set and away... JAKE'S VOICE can be heard on the SOUND-TRACK (of the FILM) ordering his camera- men not to cut... A wave of half stifled laughter here in the projection room accom- panies this... Then a  110 (contd. ) slightly embarrassed silence... Suddenly the screen goes blank. A pause...

(quietly) Let’s keep going. But nothing happens. In the shadows we can just make out JAKE as he turns an inquiring look in the direction of the projectionist. Then the door opens... But this time, no bright light is thrown on the screen. All lights, in fact, have been turned off, and what enters now through the door is an immense comic birthday cake -- a fabrication of film cans crowned with a perfect forest of kitchen candles. “Ohs!” And “ahs!” (rather campily) from the crowd... THE BARON is in charge of ceremonies (the gag is clearly his)...  111 Everyone gathers in a circle around the mass of candles, They are big kitchen candles, far too numerous to blow out in the traditional single puff. The buzz and chatter trails away into silence...
Nobody was sure just how many candles...
Looks like the Chicago fire.
(candle flames between their faces and the lens)
You should make a wish...
(after a beat) What for? (Why is that faint shadow of pain in JAKE'S eyes?)
(boringly raucous) Better start blowing -- !  112
Think you can make it, Hannaford? JAKE has caught JULIE'S eye...

Take a lotta blowing -- I’d say it’s a job for Miss Rich. She’ll huff and she’ll puff, and she’ll blow the house down -- JULIE, exchanging looks with JAKE, takes a puff at the candles -- none go out. Laughter... Everybody starts blowing... Finally the last candle is out.
Okay, let’s get back to the film... A PAUSE... Nothing happens. Has something happened to the machine? No, it’s a black-out -- The whole ranch is in
darkness.

“We didn’t just blow out the candles, we blew out a fuse!”...”Too Many camera lights -- it’s the generator -- He’s got his own out here...”  113 OTTERLAKE moves next to JAKE as he comes out of the projection room... AL (ever the eager aspirant to full membership in the CLUB) closes in from another direction.
(in one of his British voices) By God, Hannaford! This will shake the chancelleries of Europe!

(comically portentious) This is no accident, Otterlake, it’s sabotage. The “sun-guns” still work, of course. There is much flaring and glaring of these as JAKE, with MAVIS glued to his side, moves through the dark, crowded rooms... OTTERLAKE and AL follow.
(another voice) Sabotage, eh? Whom do you suspect -- that, er... cineaste? He indicates JACK SIMON
He wouldn’t know his cineaste from a hole in the ground. No, probably a midget with a grudge...

head_text.subj: SERIES OF FLASHES, (ALL OVER THE DARKENED RANCH)

text: “Y'getting anything?” "Not with color.” "Black and white, maybe...?” "Hey! -- Those South Americans -- They got tons of it. And Otto...” "Black and white? See how much we can borrow -- “ "How much’11 you pay?” "There’s a regular price -- “ "Not tonight there won't be -- ” CALB (the handy-man) having confessed his inability to deal with break-down of the ranch’s generator, quickly organizes a whole bunch of lamps and lanterns from the stables. Thus, we have been watching (in a SERIES OF DIFFERENT ANGLES) the gradual re-illumination of the party...
Saw your film...
You can’t see anymore of it tonight.
(looking around for JAKE who has suddenly vanished) Why not?
No lights, no projection, dum dum... (to SIMON) Anyway, I didn’t make it.
You will, kid, you will... Lemme tell ya what I think of it --
Hey, how about that drive-in -- ? That last little town you pass on the way out here --
Beautiful. Find one of the stooges somebody they’1l listen to --
What’s wrong with you, kid? You’‘re the one that’s good at imitations --
Do Jack Benny.
(with the same hard smile as before) Get us a drink, sweetie, go on -- two big ones...  MAVIS retreats into the shadows... 116
How’ll I find you?
Just look for Hannaford, he glows in the dark. Right, Brooksie?
(to SIMON) What you imitate is him -- The man himself. Your idea of him: the bullfights and the big game -- the whole macho bit...

The truth is, as a macho he ain’t all that much. He just likes be with ‘em. That chest ain’t near as hairy as he’d like you to think. Your guy’s a big, pink lobster -- nothing’s really tough except the shell.
Now what...? I ask you what’s so tough about you -- and you ask me if I wouldn’t like to find out; and then we entertain the guests with an old-fashioned Hollywood first fight?
If that’s how you want it, kid.  117
Old-fashioned is the word, all right! Even the way you do Jake -- Maybe he was like that thurty years ago...

I’‘1l give him forty years -- My Jake'll still lick the shit outta his. JAKE has been overhearing this... Now he steps for- ward out of the shadows, pushing JACK SIMON and (with surprising speed) rabbit punches him... SIMON doubles up for a minute; and at this, BILLY (with equally surprising speed) seizes the opportunity to blackjack him senseless ... Then, with a wicked grin, he defuses his weapon, which turns out to be an ashtray wrapped in a napkin.
(putting the ashtray back on a table) I wasn’t even here.
(to BILLY) What the hell did you do that for?
Putting a little extra zing in the old lobster’s clay Brooksie.  118 MUSIC strikes up bravely in the darkness. OTTERLAKE stares at him... He turns and starts away...
JAKE (contd. ) We'd do the same for you. We imitation Hannafords have got to stick together. PAT’S VOICE (calling) What happened, Jake? Dale -- ?
What do you think? Who knows? Johnny Dale, maybe. He could have snuck into the generator with his little monkey wrench...
Jake, I gotta talk to you...
Sure, Billy. First take care of the wounded while I say hello to Mother.  He goes...
(starting away) A couple wranglers can take him to the local first aid. We’re donating his motorcycle to charity.
I hope you aren’t proud of that, Skipper.
What do you think?
Surrounded by OTTO’S skillful arrangement of candles, MISS VALESKA is continuing her ordeal:
Okay, Zarah -- ! No romance!
We aren’t rolling.
(after another heavy little silence) I do wish you could bring yourself to open up on Jake just a little... Professionally at least --  120
Hello...
JAKE has come up behind the camera, and has been watching this last.
We don’t have much of a part, do we, Beautiful?
We made just half of a picture together.
In Austria, and what happened?
Hitler -- that’s what happened.
He threw you out, Zarah?
Miss Valeska threw him out -- Eventually. The rest of us, of course, were in there behind her, I was way behind...
But you did liberate the Ritz.  121
Her friend Ernest put in for that one -- but I was three bottles ahead of him.
(who never gives up) Pretend he isn’t here, darling -- Let’s have the truth about him...
(after a beat) Every man contains within himself the whole condition of humanity.
Write that down, somebody.
Somebody did.
(to FIONA) She gave me the book.
Mr. Hannaford always enjoys pretending to be ignorant.
And spoilt the present by telling me who gave it to her. Mr. Ossawottomie Duluth --  (These two are not so innocent as to have forgotten that the cameras exist, but by now they honestly 122
(quickly, scenting smut ) Ossie -- ?
The queers adore great women. They like all women. They’re the only sex that does.
Come on -- !
(turning to her) True: real men never like us. Men only like men... don’t care about them.)
(turning back to FIONA as he gets caught up in his theme ) And women... keep us away from each other --
Ah... “But if I cut him off,” we ask ourselves, “cut him off from all his good companions -- what will be left of him?” (pause) “An amputee, perhaps? An emotional basket case?”  123

You chop away all the same... A month's silence. Half a man is better than none. He moves away... A CAMERA following... The voices of the TV people retreating as he leaves them behind: OTTO’S VOICE (the Cameraman; after a beat) We start again? FIONA’S VOICE (murderous ) You haven't been shooting? What about these other cameras? OTTO’S VOICE They’re on their own, of course. FIONA’S VOICE Well, who the hell gave them permission -- ? JAKE moves to OTTERLAKE, taking ["Broke” } the drink out of his hand...
(after a beat) Who told you I was broke?  124
Well... Billy said you’ve lost the boat -- For a moment there’s a baleful look in JAKE’s eye as he looks up from his drink.
He did, did he...? How about the roof over my head, Brooksie, how dos that grab you?
The ranch -- ?
Out in the snow, kid -- over the hill... and down Dale -- But let’s not ever speak of Master John Dale, shall we? Ever.
(covering his extreme discomfort with a flare of temper) Dale -- ! That’s what really bugs you, isn’t it? With all your troubles -- Jesus, what’s one lousy leading man?
Less than the dust, kid, from my chariot wheels.  125
I‘ll drink to that --
(staring into his glass) You’1l never catch up with me.
That’s what I’m told... JAKE raises his eyes to him... OTTERLAKE may have expected some slight acknowledgement of this delicate compliment, but JAKE'’s look is curiously withdrawn, and almost sly.
Cute... very cute. MUSIC again... (alter- nately, Flamenco and New Orleans jazz). It continues throughout the following:
Take twenty-three.  126 He leaps nimbly out of scene... MISS VALESKA’s candles still glow enchantingly between the flowers... but no MISS VALESKA!
She’s gone!
Sun-gun...!
Well... maybe she’1ll be back.
(deep over-lap) I wouldn’t use a light like that on Miss Valeska...
(under hear breath) What could a light do to her -- ? She’s had so many face lifts, she’s ready to choke...!
In the doorway.  Silence... All the knocked
fight is out of FIONA. 127 FIONA (0.S.) (contd.) (appealing to her crew) All I did was mention the word "SEX"...
There wasn’t any.
(floundering) I’m sorry, I...
You meant with Mr. Hannaford, I suppose. (making a simple statement) There wasn’t ever... No sex at all.  128 ["MAFIA 2 + 3”]
MAGGIE has succeeded in intercepting JAKE and moves him toward a gathering of the Clan.
Frankl’s here -- he just got in from Texas...
(entering scene from another direction) I brought that teacher, Jake; I got him waiting at the pool... JAKE stops in front of HYMIE FRANKL (a long- time, part-time member of the organization).
Lousy, awful trip...
(turning to BILLY) And you -- ?
(startled) Jake! I just told you...

(quietly) That's kept you busy -- just collecting school-teachers?  129 (BILLY hopes his rueful grin will signal a reminder to JAKE that he’s also been occupied with SIMON... But there’s no indication that this registers.)
(plaintively) Hey, can I please get myself something to eat?
Didn't they feed you, Joey?
All they do on airplanes is feed you.
Turbulence...
(cheerfully) You threw up? Give him some candy, Billy.
(patiently) I didn’t “collect” the teacher, Jake, he met me at the screening --  He stops. He knows the answer... AL is behind him. 130
(quickly, quietly) With Max -- ?
Look, Jake, those oil guys, they want no part of us.
(after a short silence, cheerfully) Neither does Max -- Right, Billy?
(joining the group) Max David -- ?
That dirty crook -- who needs him?
We do...  131
Max? -- he’s so crooked he’s got rubber pockets so he can steal soup. He looks around -- not really hoping for a laugh and certainly, not getting it... They turn to find him standing nearby...
Our best chance was that oil money...
And Otterlake -- what about him?
Yes, what about me?
(a lightning quick cover-up) Brooksie! -- we just wondered if you knew about the drive-in?
(chiming in) Yes, we're screening the rest of the --
(cutting them off) He’s seen the movie --  132
Not everything.
(with his nervous little laugh) Well, we don’t have everything...
(smoothly) Leave it to Jake. Pretty soon you'll have too much.
You bet! We’ve had our troubles before...
(arranging an exit) Get you a drink, Skipper?
(acknowledging the tact) Thanks, Brooksie.
(when OTTERLAKE has left, lower- ing her voice) At Max's studio he’s the golden-haired boy, isn’t he --  133
He’s got his own company...
Tied in with Max --
That's what I mean, Billy --
(looking at BILLY) He blew it, Maggie... Must be all that candy he eats.
Me -- ?
(to BILLY) You were the one with Max -- where is he?

Not here, that’s where he is -- ! (getting a bit querulous) -- And what the hell’s the candy got to do with it? JAKE, lifting another long drink, looks at BILLY with his most sweetly patient, sacerdotal smile...  134
Could be it’s softening your brain, Uncle.

It's for the sugar... Since I got off that stuff... His eye is on JAKE’s drink... his anger makes it possible to screw up his courage and mention a very delicate matter: And speaking of which... JAKE (who knows BILLY is about to be censor- ious about the liquor) cuts in swiftly knocking him off balance:
Wasn’t very smart, y’know -- poor- mouthing like that in front of Otterlake. Know who he is, Billy?
Of course I do -- I’ve seen his pictures --
Big hits, both of ‘em --  135
(to MATT) Tell him who he is, Uncle.
Brooksie’s old man owns half the trees in Canada.
And y'know what Billy told him? He told him we’re in trouble.
Well, aren’t we? JAKE turns back to give him another steady, almost pitying look.
(very patiently) When we talk poor to the rich, William, they jump to conclusions. They think we’re getting ready for a touch.
(hushed) And that’s what we're doing?
That could have been the general idea -- Till Uncle Billy loused it up on us.  136 Poor BILLY turns away...
(lurching out of the shadows) Mr. Hannaford --
No more questions, junior --
As it happens, I did one of the earliest really positive critical appraisals --
Well, horray for you.
Well, he’s bound to feel some gratitude --
Brooksie Otterlake’s a chum... (gently, friendly -- but with a delicate hint of severity) We don’t hustle our chums for dough, kid. We’re kinda strict about that.  137 A tiny silence...
(dumbfounded) But, Mr. Hannaford -- !
Yes, kid?
Excuse me, but... didn’t I just hear you saying --

(patting PISTER gently on the cheek) Always remember... that your heart is God’s little garden... He smiles at him and ambles off into the darkness... The others trailing along after him or drifting away in different directions -- Except for MATT who moves threateningly up to the flabbergasted
That tape recorder running -- ?
Good.

But there is a camera somewhere... MATT turns sharply and squints suspiciously into the shadows... Seeing nothing, he gives PISTER another dirty look and leaves... ZIMMER’S VOICE Don’t let it bother you...
PISTER, turning near- sightedly in the direction of the voice, finds ZIMMER standing just behind him...

Studying a man like Jake Hannaford -- that’s an experience. Don’t you miss it. Stick with the job. (dropping his voice to a tone at once confiden- tial and reassuring) Eat a little shit, Mr. Pister...
Standing, rather uncertainly, in front of JAKE is DOCTOR BURROUGHS. (If he’d been born earlier, DOCTOR BURROUGHS would have been the last man in town to give up spats:)
Mr. Hannaford -- Doctor Bradley Pierce Burroughs --
Pease.
(with his brightest smile) Pease?
Bradley Pease Burroughs. (nervous laugh) Not that it matters! (holding out his hand) How do you do, sir.
The Doc here is a professor of English Literature in the Framistan Boarding Academy for Boys --
(correcting him) Clivedale -- that’s the name of the school...  140
He also teaches dramatics.
(merrily) And who do you think was my star pupil? But of course, we knew him then as “Oscar” --
Oscar?
(with a leer) Tell about Aunt Daisy -- with the funny hats. BURROUGHS is becoming increasingly aware of the cameras.
I don’t know that they were funny...
She raised him, you told me -- and ever since the first day he could walk --
Standing apart watching the curious little scene at some distance.
BURROUGHS treats JAKE a smile compounded of pity and 141
(to OTTERLAKE) What’s the point of this? MATT’S VOICE (0.S.) --. Putting on shows. All dressed up in Auntie’s gowns and hats and dresses --
(to MAGGIE) And the way Dale tells it, he didn’t even want to be an actor...
Sure; that was supposedly Jake's idea -- He practically forced him... BURROUGHS’ VOICE (0.S.) Down there in Acapulco...?
Yes, what was he doing? I mean, besides getting stoned -- to  142
Affection for his old student and the assurance that JAKE will be understanding.
(meaningfully) He made the trip just to see you...
.--. And the change of name?
For that, I’m afraid, we’ll have to blame Oscar Wilde.
Do go on, Doctor.
Well -- we had this teacher... It was one of those unpleasant little scandals...
ZARAH...she turns away. MAGGIE and OTTERLAKE
This teacher was a faggot?
143 BURROUGHS’ VOICE (0.S.) Well...
Does all this matter?
(thoughtfully) I think it does to Jake...
Mr. Hannaford... BURROUGHS, increasingly uneasy about all these busy camera surrounding him, coughs and purses his lips. The story concerns my school: I’m in no position to publish abroad a petty --

(over-lap) Publish and be damned, Doctor. Look -- they’ve run out of film -- you can speak off the record... This last is accompanied by a quick glance (almost a wink!) Into the lens of the second camera which is following...  A brief silence -- 144 BURROUGHS is still flushed with the excitement of being the center of all this attention, but by now he’s feeling quite nervous about the particular turn this multi-media interview is taking. JAKE gives him his steady “man to man” look: (A good equivalent to the straight arm on the shoulder).
Dale himself was in no way involved; but among the boys, there was a good deal of morbid conversation, I’m afraid, on unhealthy subjects. As you can imagine -- the name “Oscar”...
(in a tone of the most perfect warmth and understanding) What happened to that teacher?
We let him go, of course.
(still gently, but closing the trap) Let him go? What about the police?  145
(startled) The police? The poor man was sick, Mr. Hannaford.
Those young boys -- they weren't sick when he finished with ‘em? (hardening) That’s a prison offense, isn’t it -- How many minors do you have to corrupt?
(shocked) I hope you’re not worried about Dale...
You think I should be?
Wouldn’t that depend, Mr. Hannaford, on your own personal interest?
(after a very short beat) What are you driving at, Burroughs?
Why, nothing...  146
(cutting him off) I’m just his director, not his Aunt Daisy.
And I’m just his English teacher! (a self-conscious little laugh) JAKE looks at him for a moment... (He’s allowed the scene to get a little out of control; now he’s going to get back on top).
(with the Hannaford smile) Right!

(pulling himself together) But certainly, he has every reason to be grateful to you... (archly) And I’m sure that some day, when one of his fine performances gets the Academy Award, you'll be grateful to him.  147
(straight into camera) Notice how careful he is not to refer to it as an “Oscar.” (back to BURROUGHS) Doctor, would you care for a dip?
A dip...? In the pool? What a grand suggestion!
(turning away) A little more hootch should be helpful -- I’1l be right with you.
Good... Good. And where do I change?
(turning back) Here, Dr. Burroughs, in the sight of God; I won’t even peek.
(absorbing this) Yes...I suppose all school teachers are prigs.
I suppose so. Prigs and queers.  148
(archly) Now, now, Mr. Hannaford --
Now, now, Dr. Burroughs --
His reaction to this curious little charade...

head_text.subj: ANOTHER ROOM SOMEWHERE IN THE HOUSE

text: Big birthday surprise, eh, beautiful? He has just entered the scene... BILLY and MAGGIE follow. pause...
She doesn’t know the latest... (to ZARAH) Remember the way they met -- when Jake pulled Mr. John Dale out of the water? The famous would-be suicide --
(flatly) Would-be suicides ought to be treated like drunks.
(breaking in) Would-be suicide, hell: --
I was conned, Mother, it was a fake --
And it turns out that he doesn’t belong to you?  150 JAKE'’s smile goes a little blank.
(antagonized) Belong -- ?
The old Chinese business, remember? You save a life -- you own that life.
Finder keepers?
Do you care?
Care? We’re free for a change, eh, Uncle Bill...? Now we’ll have some fun. BILLY smiles gratefully... MAGGIE is irritated:
(to ZARAH) Jake isn’t a Chinaman --

“Chinese,” Maggie -- No, and the kid wasn’t a suicide. He was... an actor.  151 He makes the last word sound obscene... ZARAH can’t help but notice that his eyes are glazed to avoid scrutiny, he steps behind a screen and finishes undressing...
(cutting her off) We don’t own people.
He wasn’t drowning -- he was auditioning.
Or disown them. That boy didn’t run away from you. He was thrown away.
And sweet Holy Jesus, what a relief! Like getting rid of a bad tooth -- Right, Jake?

A monkey on my back -- He has stepped out from behind the screen (dressed now in a terry-cloth bath- robe)... ZARAH’s look has stopped him. That means a drug habit, in case you didn’t know, Mother... Sure -- something you gotta kick. And my foot was getting sore...  152
How will you finish it?
Finish what? He’s all washed up, Mother --
The picture... Isn’t that what matters?
We'll finish it; eh, Maggie?
Without the kid?
We do have that footage of him bringing the clothes to her... through all that wind --
To the girl?
(after another beat, unfocussed) What about her? JULIE RICH’S VOICE (0.S.) Yes, what about her?  JULIE RICH comes into scene. Enter THE BARON... 153
We're all... interested. (another beat)
He wasn’t.
Neither are you... She doesn’t interest you at all. Funny, isn’t it?
A scream.
I mean, look at the record -- the big starmaker’s never been so big females --
(holding up a length of iron pipe) Present for you... Not from me -- Zimmer. There’s a card.
(his back turned, his eyes on ZARAH) Zimmie? We oughta have a drink with Zimmie...  154
You fired him.
I always fire him. (turning to THE
Anyway, on my birthday I give the presents.
It's some kind of gag -- (he sighs) We know... You make the gags, too.
(looking at the pipe) He tells me where I can stick it?
It's for those plastic John Dales that he made for you.
Things would have been different, wouldn’t they, if Dale had been her lover -- ?
(looking in at the door ) I got an early day, Zarah, it’s been a lovely party...  155
(still zooming in on
You couldn’t manage that -- It rather spoils the pattern, doesn’t it?
What’s this pattern shit?
The big boss can tell you -- he knows how it goes -- How it’s supposed to go...
(after a beat) Well, I’m going home -- What’s that thing?
(half to herself, angrily turning away ) Zimmie's jokes -- !
Speaking of presents... JAKE has been rummaging in a drawer. He brings something out and, turning with it, is haulted again by MATT’s voice reading from ZIMMER'’s “birthday card”:  156
(reading) “Have a go at the dummies, Jake -- they break even more easily than people.” After a moment’s pause, JAKE turns again and moves out to --
(INCLUDING THE ACTRESS)

(making an announcement ) Gentlemen -- and Ladies... The clot of cameras thickens quickly around him... We're presenting an award... To the other half of “The Other Side Of The Wind”... the better half. A glint of alcohol in his eye, he moves toward THE ACTRESS. A bone for Pocohontas... The crowd watches in uneasy silence (THE ACTRESS very cool)...  He pauses for effect. His eyes move to THE ACTRESS. 157 JAKE (contd. ) A little curio we picked up somewhere -- A bit of our own palefaced craftsmanship: an Indian bone... The inscription goes back before all this was movie country. Just after the gold was found. The redskin population dropped pretty quickly then -- ten years and ninety thousand of ‘em just... disappeared. Well, in those good old days, our gallant honkey pioneers used to cut themselves some heads off Indian skulls and pickle the ears in whisky for souvenirs -- And on bones, like this one, they liked to write cute little jokes -- (reading the inscription) “I am off the reservation at last.” And so you are, my dear... He lays the bone down on a table next to her quite gently, and speaks quite lightly.
We thought you might want to give this to your leading man -- right up his ass.  158

Between carious types... including some notable celebrities. All this (like everything else) is recorded by the documentary camera-crew, and also video-freaks)... As the party continues, the generation gap is underscored by the choice of intoxicants. Guests anywhere near HANNAFORD’s age are, of course, mostly on booze... JAKE himself is quietly putting it away in fairly Homeric quantities... At this stage, he certainly isn’t sober. (THE DWARVES are frankly drunk)...  159

A fine array of trophies, a magnificent gun collection and many framed photographs (groups on safari and convivial gatherings aboard the Hannaford yacht). AL is studying one of the pictures. It shows a handsome young man tensely profiled in front of some battered targets and clay pigeons.
Who’s the joker with the cigarette?
Miguel -- He was the best of all.
Best of what?
Our bullfighters, right, Jake? We followed him for a while all over Spain.
(to JAKE, who has just entered with
That’s you, aiming the gun at him in the shooting gallery...  160
Another birthday, kid. And what a party that was -- No movie buffs or bums, no spies or spooks. Just paid- up members of The Club.
(reading the sign- ture on the photo) Miguel Ortega?
The best.
Didn't he get killed?
Yep.
(grinning as he continues to study the photograph) I hope you weren’t responsible for that.
I just got that one shot at him, Brooksie, and I missed.  161
CBut he got the cigarette. (he starts out the door) There was never any braver.
(following THE BARON) Not in a shooting gallery.
No, he didn’t look too good in there.

I guess he didn’t quite trust you -- (he breaks off, with a quick change of tone) Drop that gun, Skipper. JAKE has indeed, picked out a rifle from his gun collection. If you're planning to celebrate this birthday on me just --

This is the one that hurts, Brooksie... (OTTERLAKE is so good at dead-panning a gag that we almost wonder if he does imagine the old man is proposing some sort of lunatic duel?)  162 JAKE looks up at him, as the young director rises abruptly to his feet. Silence...
Skipper --

(cutting him off) This is the scene we both hoped that we'd never get to. And I don’t think it’s going to play. Not even for comedy. He raises the gun and sights along it, pointing out the window --. He pulls the trigger. It clicks. The gun is empty. He lowers it, and turns, faintly smiling to OTTERLAKE... A short silence... Then:
How much longer do you need?

How much longer have you got? OTTERLAKE tries to answer... JAKE gets up and leans the gun against the wall.  Silence... Silence... 163 JAKE (contd. ) Hey -- remember when you first appeared on that location of mine up in Bolivia? What is it -- just three years ago?
(forcing a chuckle) I didn’t even have the fare back home, just a second-hand tape recorder that I couldn’t work --
A raggedy-ass kid...
Skipper...
Yeah?
That forty million that was mentioned...
I know, kid; let me finish your line for you. It’s still only a distant hope... How’s that for dialogue?  164 He grins at him and moves into the bathroom.
(from the bathroom) You might just lean a little on Max David... You do the leaning, he’s gotta give.
I did set up the screening --
So you did... He hated every frame --
He was confused...
Sure.
He’s an idiot, Jake. You know that. They're all idiots.
He’s your idiot.
Up to a point.
Don’t be pompous, kid... Not that I don’t understand. You made the company all that loot. Christ knows I didn’t.  165
Don’t think I’m not going to put up a fight about it. I will. JAKE comes to the door. JAKE looks at him... He starts raising the gun...
But you don’t want to.
I don’t want to have to listen to Max and the rest of those stupid sods turning you down... We'll find a way... You know that, don’t you?
Don’t give up the ship, Davey...?
I’m not -- !
Didn't I tell you -- ? This scene will never play...  166

head_text.subj: THE ROW OF DUMMIES ON THE ROCKS

text: (placed earlier in neat arrangement by ZIMMER)... The head of one of them is suddenly hit by a bullet and destroyed.
Firing...

THE ACTRESS sits alone on one of them. (We are across the pool from the firing lines where the dummies are still getting blown to smithereens by the sportsmen in the window of the gun room. ) HIGGAM enters scene.
(out of sorts) I’ve been looking for you... She turns to look at him. HIGGAM (contd. ) Your boss sent me --
Not liking that word "boss"... HIGGAM’S VOICE (0.S.) I’m supposed to give you this --  167
Holding out a gun...
Another present?

How do I know? He just told me that he thinks you’1l know how to use it. Rising and taking the gun from him, she looks dangerous... HIGGAM beats a hasty retreat. She then raises the gun, turning to aim it directly away from the row of dummies...
His eyes are on THE ACTRESS
(from a place of safety) Who’s she aiming at?
(after a beat) Me. A shot rings out, and the lantern nearest to JAKE shatters to pieces.  168
Hey -- !
(falling into the hammy style of their game) Otterlake -- we never should have issued firearms to the natives. Another shot! And another lantern breaks. The group is practically blacked out.
She turns her gun slightly, taking careful aim --
Getting their plaster heads blown off!!
Each with a gun, firing blithely away...
Mother naked, scuttling frantically out of range of the flying bullets.
She’s nuts! She’s going to wreck the whole damn party --  169
Jake’s done that already.

Suddenly -- Out of the blackness, a bolt of bright raspberry colored lightning (!!!) Reveals the Hannaford Ranch, the Western landscape surrounding it, and DR. BURROUGHS, crouched behind cactus, a trembling nude... The scattered dummies on the rocks look like an over-exposed negative of some unthinkable massacre... The lightning changes color -- luridly, repeatedly, and t night is hideously assaulted with noise. What has commenced, of course, is a display of fireworks. An important display -- if a bit in spirit... Guests are surprised in various attitudes and positions...  170 A mighty boom (!!!) from some larger and louder firework.
What was that?
(as PATTON) Artillery. The heavy stuff. A new -- a really terrific detonation!!! The women-folk’s all safe in the stockade?
(just beginning to dig) One of them’s been shooting at me --
Tiny figures, like demons from hell, can be seen on top of the house scuttling madly about in the smoke and flame...

head_text.subj: THE FRONT OF THE RANCH HOUSE

text: (his Blimp character) My God, Hannaford -- there are lots of them -- little men up there -- shooting Roman candles on the roof!
171 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (changing voices) Veteran troops, old boy -- Neo-realistics. (another voice) And the grand, old New Wave, sir. They’1ll never give up!
(Spooked or bored, put off or turned on -- according to age group and individual temperament)...
Exploding bouquets of light... wheels of colored flame.. of white fire...
Look -- that sweet old lady in the tennis shoes --
(looking wildly around) Where?
(sharply correcting him) Y’mean who.  172 AL (contd. ) (then, with lowered voice -- confidentially) Governor Reagan -- that’s who!
